text: in this tutorial I'm gonna show you
everything you need to know about
automation in Ableton Live 10 okay so
what is automation first off automation
is basically a way to control different
parameters and any of your instruments
were effects within Ableton without
actually having to manually control them
so if we wanted to control the filter
frequency of a synth like this manually
you can see that we'd have to do that
with multiple hands and unless your
octopus with millions of hands that's
impossible so what we can do with
Ableton is actually programming what's
called automation to do that for us so
let's go through everything you need to
know I'm going to be using arrangement
mode because I tend not to use
automation in clip mode which is here I
don't use clip mode much so we're just
going to be doing it in arrangement mode
make sure that automation mode is
selected with this button here and you
can select that by pressing a on your
keyboard and it's going to turn it on
and off so all you have to do is
right-click then press show automation
or you can press show automation in new
Lane and it just shows it below which
allows you to automate several things at
once so for instance we could automate
the pan and it's going to show it
underneath and we can just press this
little arrow to hide them if needs be
and then show our automation lanes so
let's have a listen we can hear the
filter opening up but there's also some
other automation going on so what else
have I got I'm actually automating the
send amount so we're automating the
amount of room reverb on our auxiliary
channel that's being applied and this is
the great thing about automation you can
do loads of things at once and then that
allows us to yeah have a million things
happening at once
so that's the basics of what automation
is now if you tweak something whilst
you're whilst you've got some automation
already programmed in like this filter
frequency you're gonna see this button
here turn on and go orange and you'll
see this little line here this little
dot sorry turn from orange into gray and
that basically means that we're
overriding the automation temporarily
now until we click this button again
it's going to go back to the automation
we got programmed in so if we move this
like so let me just and you can choose
from these drop-down menus which
automations are showing and the ones
that you forgot programmed in I've got
these little orange dots on it next to
them which makes them nice and easy so
the top is the actual unit so the
effects unit or the synthesizer or the
sampler and then below that is the
actual parameter itself so here we can
see you've got this which is the
frequency but if we move this frequency
whilst it's playing these lines will go
white instead of orange and then it's
not going to actually go back to what we
have programmed in until we press this
button here cool so there the basics
next thing we are going to look at is
the different lines that you can use in
Ableton Live 10 so you can do it a nice
straight line there and you just double
click to create a node so you can do you
know loads of different nodes if you
want but you can also hold alt on your
keyboard and then drag the line to make
a slope so you can make it an
exponential curve or a logarithmic curve
and that just gives you a bit more
control over the exact shape that you
want
okay next copying and pasting
automations now the default is if you
select your clip and you press copy and
then paste it is going to copy the clip
and the automation if you just want to
copy the automation then you select it
here rather than selecting the whole
clip you can select
here and then paste and it's just gonna
paste the automation see the clip hasn't
been copied or if you want to copy the
clip but not the automation you just
press this little lock thing and that
locks the automation so we can then
paste the clip but you'll see that
automation hasn't been copied from that
first place but what happens if you
don't want to draw in the automation
like this and you'd rather record it
either by assigning some of the
parameters to a MIDI controller or you
just want to tweak the parameters
manually with your mouse as you go or
the way you do that is you select the
overdub button here which means that
you're not going to be recording over
your MIDI information you select the
automation record button here you make
sure that the track you want to automate
is armed like so and then you just press
record two more things one is that you
can use macros to control multiple
parameters at once or automate multiple
parameters but at once so if you grab
everything that you want to automate in
terms of instruments and press command +
G which will group them into an
instrument rack if you press this little
button here you can see that you've got
these macro controls and all you need to
do then is well we'll select map to
macro one and we will map something else
to macro one and we'll map something
else to macro one this is going to be
really weird by the way I'm just giving
you an example of what you might do
let's do the dry and wet on that - macro
one and then you can just Matt you can
just automate this one control show
automation in new Lane and it's going to
control all of these parameters just
from this one automated knob so
automated macro
